title: Social Media Reboot: A Conversation with Jay Graber
text:
Transcript

[upbeat music]

Hey guys.

[audience applauding]

Hello.

Yes, I'm WIRED senior writer Kate Knibbs,

and I'm thrilled to be joined today by the CEO

of the hottest social network of the moment, Jay Graber.

Before Jay was the CEO of Bluesky,

she founded a social platform

and she also was vital to the development

of the privacy-focused cryptocurrency Zcash.

So she's done a real tour of Silicon Valley activities

and yeah, it's gonna be great.

Thanks for being here.

Thanks for having me, Kate.

Yeah, so I joined Bluesky about a year ago,

and at the time it was still invite only

and it was, you know, really, really popular

amongst a certain community,

but recently it's completely exploded

and grown exponentially.

How many users are on there now?

We crossed 24 million recently.

Amazing.

And since it's grown so much,

I'm curious if you can explain to anyone

who is still unfamiliar with the platform,

what distinguishes Bluesky from its competitors?

Yeah, so Bluesky's really focused on user choice.

We try to give users a choice in their experience,

developers the freedom to build,

and creators the ability

to own their relationship with their audience.

And so the way that we do that

is it's built on an open network underneath.

And that means that there's lots of experiences

that you can have on Bluesky.

You can customize your feed, you can control what you see,

you can control how other people interact with you.

There's a lot of tooling under the hood for that.

And so that means that it's a better experience for people

and ultimately that's what we're trying to provide.

And, you know, it is a crowded playing field

and you are emerging as like a new star.

I'm wondering why do you think, you know, it was,

the world was so ready for innovation in this space?

Yeah, well social has gotten kind of stagnant

over the years.

When you have really strong network effects

and people feel like they can't leave

and there's no alternative,

then innovation kind of comes to a halt.

Also, the social companies have closed down the ability

for developers to build on them.

And so stuff that used to happen,

like people building, you know, TweetDeck back in the day,

stuff like that, doesn't really happen anymore.

And so what we've done is opened that back up again.

So developers are building new things

and users are coming in and finding out that,

hey, you can do things differently here.

You can have a model of a social network

that lets you be social again

and isn't, you know, having a for-you feed

that just shows you what the algorithm wants you to see.

There's the ability for you to go in

and search for whatever you want,

see whatever you wanna see,

and if you can't find it, you can go build it.

I really, really appreciate that the search bar

doesn't say anything about AI.

I thank you for that.

Is there anything that, you know,

people, developers, or other people in the Bluesky community

are doing that's especially exciting to you?

Yeah, there's a lot of stuff that's been built

that's really cool and that we're seeing for the first time.

One of them is starter packs.

So people are using this tool we built

to connect with each other.

And so if you want to bring your friend on, you can add,

you know, your hundred most recommended accounts

or however many you want to a starter pack

and then give that link to your friend

or even put up a QR code and give that to people.

And so that means that people

are able to find their network very quickly.

The other thing people have done is

they've built tons of custom feeds.

And so that means that if you are just looking

for maybe cat pictures today, that's all you wanna see.

[Kate] I, that's usually me.

Yeah, you can search for that

or you can just install a feed

that just shows you cat pictures.

People have built multiple of these.

And so this gives people a way to customize their experience

more than they've ever been able to do before.

That is amazing.

And I think there was a QR code showing a starter pack.

Hopefully you guys all held your phones up and got that.

But, yeah, it's, I love the starter packs.

That's kind of, I know WIRED has one.

Yeah, there we go. There we go.

So, one of the parts of Bluesky

that I've been really curious to see how it develops,

is, you know, for a long time Twitter

had verification badges

and that helped journalists, and government officials,

and celebrities, and people who might be impersonated,

or might otherwise just really wanna prove

that they are who they say they are.

You know, the verification badges were sort of the way

that most of the major social networks

went about offering that service.

Right now on Bluesky, the verification process

I honestly find con kind of convoluted.

Even though I'm a WIRED writer and I should be tech savvy,

I really struggle to understand how to verify myself

because you have to put your own domain name,

you have to register.

I'm not even gonna do a good job explaining it,

but it's kind of complicated.

And as you're scaling up, I'm wondering, you know,

are you starting to think of other ways

to verify accounts that are perhaps simpler?

What is your plan there?

Yeah, this has actually been a topic of discussion

on the network this week,

but I can back up and explain the verification

that we do have right now,

which is intended to put user control front and center.

And so that is the custom domain name system.

So if you are the New York Times, you know,

you can have that just be your domain, right?

WIRED I think is also, you know, their own domain.

And so that means that you're able to

show whoever owns this website

is the person behind the account.

And so that means, you know, even senators

can get a senate.gov domain

and only a person who controls the senate.gov domain name

can give that to people.

So this is a way for organizations or well-known websites

to self-verify without needing someone in the middle,

like us, to do that.

But that is a little bit complicated.

We have the ability for you

to actually buy your own domain name through us,

but that's not necessarily what everyone wants,

particularly people already have their own domains.

Is is buying your own domain name a profit center for you?

It's something that we actually just put out

to try to make it easier for people

because that way you don't have to set it up yourself.

And also people like shorter usernames.

And so, you know, everyone has a bsky.social

if you don't have your own custom domain.

And so if you just want like, I don't know, jay.com,

I could buy that and then have that as my username.

And so it creates a shorter link,

shorter handle you can have.

But the way that we're talking

about exploring new ways of verification,

and this is being done sort of in the open on GitHub,

on the network people are chatting about it,

is putting out some form of verification

where we will be one verifier

and then others can verify as well.

And so, because again, going back

to this being an open network,

that means that, you know,

we could verify some organizations,

some people have some process for that,

maybe display a badge or something, you know.

We haven't come to a final conclusion on this yet,

but then other folks could do that as well.

And so you could have other organizations,

other people out there

doing their own verification processes.

And then as a user you can decide which you want to trust.

And so,

if you wanna trust Bluesky's check mark system, you can,

that'll probably be a default,

but if you wanna install a different one

or, you know, use a different version of it,

you can go and search for that.

And so that means that the trust is ultimately rooted

in what you as the user want to see

as the verification system you believe in.

So Bluesky itself wouldn't be verifying

the other verification systems.

The app is always able

to do some amount of customization over like, you know,

what things we recommend.

So, for example, we have tons of feeds,

we have tons of moderation services,

and we might recommend some

because these have been around for a while.

These are more trusted.

But over time I think people, including us,

start to build up trust in the systems that work best.

And so, you know, one that just popped up last night

probably won't be at the top of the search results

and people won't be using it a lot.

But if there's, you know, a credible organization behind it

where a lot of people are using it,

then that'll rise to the top.

Gotcha. Okay, very interesting.

WIRED might have to start up its own verification service.

So Jay and I actually talked

for the first time last February,

and one of the most memorable things she said to me

was that she was determined that Bluesky

would not become inshitified with advertisements.

Yes. [audience members clapping]

A lot has happened since then though.

You know, I don't think,

I've always been a fan of this service,

but I didn't expect it to take off in the way that it did

in the past few months.

You've scaled in a way that is really unique

and at the same time you've also, you know,

taken some venture capital investments.

I just can, I can imagine

that there's more pressure than ever

to figure out ways to be profitable.

I'm wondering, you know,

how are you gonna be profitable

without inshitifying the platform?

Yeah, I mean our goal from the start has been to make sure

that our incentives end up aligned with users

and the people who've built this ecosystem.

And so the ways that we're moving into monetization is,

as we announced recently, starting with subscriptions.

But we're gonna go into, you know,

exploring some other avenues here.

One of the things we really believe

is that money follows value.

So we've started to, you know,

a lot of the effort we've put in is just showing

that there's value in having an open network

and being able to build on it

and other people can participate in that.

So people building feeds, building moderation services,

building the things that are, you know,

making this a valuable ecosystem.

And so our goal in moving into that

is to build some network services,

things that, you know, developers can tap into,

you know, users can tap into.

And, you know, not necessarily going to go into great detail

on all this right now,

but like subscriptions are the first step.

And then from there we're gonna explore things that like,

keep our incentives aligned with the ecosystem.

Are you going to roll out subscriptions soon?

That was the plan, but we've had a lot of growth recently

and so right now it's a bit in flux.

Yeah, what has been, you know, the hardest part

of growing at this rate?

Well, we have a pretty small team.

We have 24 million users and a core team of 20 employees.

And so we're focusing on scaling,

we're focusing on making sure

that it remains a good experience as we scale

and really delivering the features that, you know,

become urgent as, you know, new types of users come on

and new types of problems arise.

Like you mentioned, verification was something that,

you know, we've, from the start,

talked about open ways to do verification

that allows other people to participate in the process,

but that's sort of need for it now

has accelerated those discussions.

Gotcha.

One thing that a lot of people have brought up to me

when I've told them that I'm gonna interview you

is, you know, since Bluesky has exploded in popularity,

there are certain groups of people

who are really, really taking to the network.

Journalists are one of the groups, you know.

Journalists, I think, we're all so overjoyed

to have a place to post links to our stories

that doesn't throttle them,

that we're like just beyond thrilled.

There has been this major exodus from X

in the wake of the election,

but also even prior to the election,

a lot of people had issues

with the way that Elon Musk was running it.

So there's a large influx of people

who basically share a worldview, share ideologies.

You know, I'd say most people would agree

that right now the majority of people using Bluesky

are liberal.

And I've had a lot of conversations with people

who really like the app but are worried

that it's just never going to reach a network effect

of bringing in people that aren't liberals,

bringing in, you know, people from the right,

you know, people are worried

that it's just gonna be an echo chamber basically.

And I'm curious if you are worried about that.

Like I could see a world in which you'd just decide

that that's the lane that you're in

and you're gonna stick with it,

but then that obviously limits growth.

Basically I'm asking like, do you want all the people

that are still on X to come join Bluesky?

Do you want people who are far right to be on Bluesky?

Like what, what is your hope for what the user base

is gonna look like going forward?

Well, at the end of the day,

we set out to change the way social media works

from the bottom up.

That's why we built on an open protocol,

that's, you know, how we got started.

And so our goal is to build this for everyone.

Bluesky's for everyone.

We have the ability for people

to create the spaces that they want.

And even now,

there's actually lots of Blueskies within Bluesky

because you're able to create so much customization.

And so the way this works is we just try to give the users

as many controls as possible.

So whoever, you know, posts a thread has controls over,

you know, what happens in that thread to some degree, right?

Because we're thinking about this as your Bluesky account

being like your own blog.

It's actually similar,

because you actually can host your own data,

your own account, on your own service if you want.

And so just like a person who puts up a blog post

can go in and, you know, have some control

over their comment section,

the person who posts a thread

on Bluesky, on your micro blog,

gets to have that kind of control.

And then if somebody is, you know, quote posting you

and you wanna get outta this conversation,

you're not feeling it, you can remove yourself

from those quote-posts.

And so that means that, you know, some people say,

well this starts to create an echo chamber

because you're not, you know, listening.

But actually there's just a lot of ways

that social media has gotten a bit tiring

for a lot of people

because you can't necessarily get out of the conversations

you don't wanna be in

unless you completely stop using the app.

And so our goal is to get things to a point, you know,

with the way that we're building this app

that people have controls over

how they wanna spend their time online.

And so you can go in and design a experience

that is just quiet posters and mutuals,

if you really want that.

And that's just-

What's a quiet poster?

Yeah, so those are actually feeds that people have built

that mean that it just shows you posts

from people you follow that don't post that often.

So maybe you have that friend

that uses social media like once a month

and normally they'll get drowned out

in the people who are posting every hour

and you would never see their posts.

But if you go into that feed, then you're seeing the people

who, you know, who have just posted over the past few weeks

or the past month and you catch up on that.

And then the mutuals are people who

I follow you and you follow me,

and then I like to hear from the people who I already know

and like, that's the conversation I wanna be in.

And then if you wanna go dip in

and see what's going on in the broader world,

you can go to say the Discover feed

or the Politics and News feed,

and check in on everything going by,

maybe participate in those conversations

and then, you know, swipe away from that

or uninstall them when you're done

with that kind of a conversation.

And so that means that the people who come on here

start to be able to design the spaces that they want.

Do you think then in that way

that people will be able to design experiences

that they want,

but that means they'll be able to exclude, you know,

seeing posts that they don't wanna see?

Do you think that that's gonna basically put a limit

on how much Bluesky can ever sort of simulate a town square?

There's the spaces where those kinds

of broad town square discussions are happening as well,

but following our philosophy of just giving users control,

I think it's up to the user what they want to see.

Because I think when people don't wanna participate

in that kind of discussion,

they just don't use that app anymore.

Or they withdraw to, you know, a text message group

or a discord group or someplace where they feel

like they can be having the conversations

with the people that they want,

and then they come back when they want to,

you know, talk to strangers

about all the stuff happening in the moment.

We want to make it possible

to talk about everything happening in the moment,

all the broader conversations going on,

and have that be going by.

And then you can dip in and out of that stream as you wish.

And the ability to link to stuff,

as you mentioned really easily,

and follow through on those links, is another part of this,

which is just seeing Bluesky as being a gateway

to the open web.

We wanna make social more like the web again.

And so that means that, you know,

you can click through, like we love links.

We want you to be able to, you know,

go through to where people are having conversations,

not even just on the app,

but if you're going to go, you know,

read that news article and then comment on it,

Your personal Bluesky experience when you're designing it,

what are you prioritizing?

Are you going, you know,

are you treating it more like discord situation?

Are you going for these mutuals and quiet posters?

Like what, what are, what's your ideal, you know,

scroll through Bluesky look like?

I actually do both

because I wanna catch up on what's going on

and there's actually a Catchup feed

that shows you the most popular posts in the last 24 hours.

And so I like to go through

and see what everyone else has been talking about,

like get the vibe of the network that day

and then see what the Discover feed shows me.

But then sometimes I actually do

go into the quiet posters or mutuals feed.

There's also one I really like called the Moss feed,

which is just like forest pictures

people have taken on their hikes

and because it's picking the stuff up in an automated way

from everything people post,

these are people who, you know, maybe a new user came on

and just posted a picture of a hike

with a mossy rock or something.

And it's just like stepping out of the stream

of all the broader conversations for a moment

and just visiting a quiet corner of the network.

And then, you know, I don't spend all day on there,

but then I go back to what else is going on,

maybe make a post.

And so that's within my experience of the app,

I can have these different corners of it for myself.

I'm definitely gonna check out the Moss feed.

I love a bog.

It's one of my favorites.

Yeah.

Five years from now, where do you want Bluesky to be?

I want to change the way social works.

I want us to have choice over what we see,

to have an open marketplace of different algorithms,

different timelines.

I want us to have lots of people participating

in building moderation services.

So these questions about how social media is moderated,

who controls what you see, gets placed back in users' hands,

in developers' hands,

and in the hands of anyone who's interested

in helping improve the situation, right?

Like civil society organizations,

academic researchers who have ideas

for how social could be different.

I had a talk recently with some folks

who are exploring pro-social algorithms.

So how do we get people

to have better conversations with each other,

maybe from different perspectives

or different parts of political spectrum

through the ways that we build the algorithms actually.

So instead of highlighting the most outrage

or the most engagement generating things,

which aren't necessarily

causing people to change their minds,

but maybe actually driving them further apart.

What if we build things that find the commonalities

and bring people together?

And those kinds of experiments

can be done on Bluesky right now

because those researchers can build a feed,

spin it up, get users to try it,

and they don't have to go lobby a company for change

or lobby regulators for change.

They can just experiment with what if we just change

this app that's giving us the ability to get our hands in

and start, you know, making changes right now.

I would love to test one of those algorithms out someday.

Okay, we don't have that much time left,

but I do need to ask you about something.

So I was talking

to our editor in chief, Katie Drummond, earlier,

and she's a big Bluesky fan too.

And I was talking about something that I had skeeted

and she like visibly recoiled

and she doesn't like the phrase,

and if you guys aren't aren't familiar,

Bluesky's user base basically took it upon itself

to call what you put out into the feed a skeet

It's kind of a play on a tweet

and it doesn't have any other meaning.

So, you know, and now that you're blowing up,

like are we sticking with skeet?

I have always called them posts.

[audience and Jay laughing]

I maintain that they are called posts

because when we set out to do this,

we were not trying to invent new words,

and we were building a protocol.

So there's gonna be other apps, there are other apps,

there's other things people use

and not all of them are going to call posts the same thing.

On the other hand, this is very user-driven

and, you know, the ecosystem evolves as it will.

So I'm gonna keep calling them posts.

The Bluesky app, when you go to post something

says post and quote post,

but there's other apps out there

that have called them skeets.

Do you have a favorite post?

Like one of those that

use rent free- My, yeah,

Like is there any, is there any,

I was gonna say do you have a favorite skeet,

but I'll call 'em posts.

Like, is there a platonic ideal of a Bluesky post

that you look at and you think like,

Yeah, I did a good job.

Like what's your favorite skeet?

Let's see.

Well the one that sprang to mind

is somebody made a joke about vitamin water

that I still remember,

and they said, you know, Oh, it's vitamin water.

What vitamins does it have in it?

Pink.

And that's how I feel about vitamin water,

but I still love it.

So I don't know why I thought of that,

but that's one of the ones I like.

There's just a lot of posts like that

that go by and make me laugh.

No, I'm honestly very, very impressed

that you came up with one on the spot

'cause I didn't tell her I was gonna ask her that.

That is all the time that we have.

But, Jay, thank you so much for joining us and-

[Jay] Thank you.

Everyone should get a Bluesky account.

[audience applauding]
